</image>   <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;398bd496.1503">   <title>TLC webinar: EPCC MOOC: Massive, Open Online & Personal? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;398bd496.1503</link>   <description> Reminder<br>Apologies for cross posting<br><br>Teaching and Learning Conversations (TLC)<br>David Eddie (@sonofedd),Teaching Fellow (DL), Faculty of Health and Wellbeing, from Sheffield Hallam University will lead an exciting webinar on Tuesday the 24th of March, 12-1pm GMT* during which we will consider<br>Enhancing Prostate Cancer Care MOOC: Massive, Open Online &amp; Personal?<br>The EPCC MOOC was delivered through digital workbooks in PebblePad. The webinar will explore some of the key principles of the learning design and challenges presented by delivery via a Personal Learning Space.The webinar will incorporate some interactive elements to illustrate opportunities provided in the EPCCMOOC to amplify [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-12T10:24:36+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Middleton, Andrew</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;398bd496.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;39cdf94d.1503">   <title>Educational Development post at Lancaster University </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;39cdf94d.1503</link>   <description> Dear Colleagues<br><br>An exciting educational development post has become available in our department.<br><br>We would be really grateful if you could forward this link with all the details to anyone who you think might be interested<br>http://hr-jobs.lancs.ac.uk/Vacancy.aspx?ref=A1209<br><br>With thanks<br><br>Ali<br><br>Ali Cooper | PFHEA, MA, MEd, PGCE |<br>Educational Development Adviser | Organisation &amp; Educational Development |<br>a.m.cooper@lancaster.ac.uk&lt;mailto:a.m.cooper@lancaster.ac.uk&gt; | 01524 510632 | HR Building | Lancaster University | LA1 4YW | [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T17:39:15+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Cooper, Alison</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;39cdf94d.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8cc6b80e.1503">   <title>launch of The PhD Survival Video next Monday </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8cc6b80e.1503</link>   <description> The official launch of The PhD Survival Video, about PhDs, stress and mental health, takes place next Monday March 16th. Kindly hosted by the Birkbeck Institute for Social Research, the event includes a screening of the video, discussion of the issues raised and a buffet lunch. Bookings have exceeded expectations, and Birkbeck have moved the event to a larger room, so a few places are now available. Visit http://www.bbk.ac.uk/bisr/events/bbk-local?uid=f2d22110c25578cdb4cad65ad85c2020 for details and to book. If you cannot come but would like a free preview of the video, please email ac@angelproductions.co.uk. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T15:31:51+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Stephen Engelhard</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8cc6b80e.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;269398b.1503">   <title>Re: Defining the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL) </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;269398b.1503</link>   <description> Dear colleagues<br><br>Attached please find my summary of the very interesting set of comments<br>I received. Many thanks to those you contributed. I hope there are<br>points of interest to all.<br><br>Best regards, Carmel<br><br>On 2/9/2015 7:35 AM, Carmel wrote:<br>&gt; ...<br>&gt;<br>&gt; This is also a 'holding' message of thanks to the many colleagues who<br>&gt; have sent ideas and references to me in the past week. The HERDSA call<br>&gt; for ideas will only appear on Wednesday (HERDSA does a weekly<br>&gt; compilation). So, it might be a couple more weeks before I send a<br>> summary [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T16:12:37+04:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Carmel</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;269398b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e101302f.1503">   <title>Re: Plagiarism CPD resources for new staff? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e101302f.1503</link>   <description> Whilst being a bit un -PC - this is a fun plagarism video<br><br>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mwbw9KF-ACY<br><br>On 9 March 2015 at 15:30, Bridget Middlemas &lt;B.Middlemas@roehampton.ac.uk&gt;<br>wrote:<br><br>&gt; Dear SEDA Colleagues<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt; I wonder if any you can recommend some useful resources or websites on<br>&gt; plagiarism that we can use with new academic staff? Does anyone run<br>&gt; specific CPD workshops on this topic?<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt; If you could reply to me off- list, that would be great, at:<br>&gt; b.middlemas@roehampton.ac.uk . I will share the ideas once I have<br>&gt; collated them.<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>> [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-09T15:34:47+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ian Scott</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e101302f.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f4320f67.1503">   <title>Plagiarism CPD resources for new staff? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f4320f67.1503</link>   <description> Dear SEDA Colleagues<br><br>I wonder if any you can recommend some useful resources or websites on plagiarism that we can use with new academic staff? Does anyone run specific CPD workshops on this topic?<br><br>If you could reply to me off- list, that would be great, at: b.middlemas@roehampton.ac.uk&lt;mailto:b.middlemas@roehampton.ac.uk&gt; . I will share the ideas once I have collated them. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-09T15:30:49+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Bridget Middlemas</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f4320f67.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;314f08c1.1503">   <title>FW: UK Academic Advising and Personal Tutoring Network One-Day Conference </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;314f08c1.1503</link>   <description> Academic Advising and Personal Tutoring Conference \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 25 March 2015<br><br>The University of Sheffield is proud to host the launch of a UK Allied Group of NACADA through a one-day conference event on the 25th of March, 2015.<br><br>NACADA, the Global Community for Academic Advising, promotes student success by advancing the field of academic advising. NACADA provides opportunities for professional development, networking and leadership for their diverse membership. The launch will feature key sessions from noted professionals in NACADA, including Charlie Nutt and Jennifer Joslin. Its focus will extend to UK practices and contexts, helping to establish formal sharing of [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-09T14:31:59+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Rupert Ward (SCOM)</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;314f08c1.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5bdb8fcb.1503">   <title>Final Week to Early Bird Registration! Higher Education Conference in Singapore: International Conference on Learning & Teaching (29 Sep - 1 Oct 2015) </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5bdb8fcb.1503</link>   <description> Dear SEDA Colleagues,<br><br>Early bird registration closes on 16 March 2015. Join us for a higher education conference in Singapore. We'd be delighted to have you register for Temasek Polytechnic's International Conference on Learning &amp; Teaching&lt;http://www.tp.edu.sg/2015conf&gt; (29 Sep - 1 Oct 2015), held in conjunction with our Polytechnic's 25th anniversary.<br><br>We have confirmed six internationally renowned speakers: Professor David Boud, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia; Professor Cindy Hmelo-Silver, Indiana University Bloomington, USA; Professor Dai Hounsell, University of Edinburgh, UK; Professor Tan Oon Seng, National Institute of Education, Singapore; Professor Norman Vaughan, Mount Royal University, Canada; and Professor Dylan Wiliam, Institute [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-09T05:02:13+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Lee Gek Choo, Moira</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5bdb8fcb.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a1525a3c.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a1525a3c.1503</link>   <description> Dear all<br><br>I have been following the debates about styles and hope this contribution helps. In relation to some of the areas mentioned in emails, what we know from robust research integrating neuroscience, cognitive psychology, and education perspectives is that individuals use different levels of information processing and different cognitive style families when engaged in learning. This means each individual has the capacity to use a range of styles although some learners are better than others at self-regulating and in using the most appropriate style(s) in a context. It is therefore not possible to match one style as we have [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-07T16:28:45+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Evans C.A.</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a1525a3c.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;92e6a166.1503">   <title>Re: [1] Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;92e6a166.1503</link>   <description> Emma/Andrew I'd be interested to know more about that framework.<br>Personally, I think social psychology can give at least some account of<br>those complex relationships you mentioned.<br><br>So, by way of an example, hearing a bird call might activate the<br>'bird-watchers' identity as long as you identify yourself as a member of<br>that social group (bird-watchers). With that identity activated, you might<br>then pick up your binoculars to look because its part of what group-members<br>do on that group-relevant activity (their norms). You may not do that<br>secondary activity (looking with or without binoculars) if you just heard<br>it as [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T18:42:29+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nicholas Bowskill</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;92e6a166.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;80a04fd2.1503">   <title>Re: [1] Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;80a04fd2.1503</link>   <description> Bland, I'd regard that as *physical* diversity distinct from *cognitive*<br>diversity. They will influence each other won't they but its not quite the<br>same starting point. In any case, I think the available senses would still<br>function in the same situationally-sensitive manner wouldn't they?<br><br>Best Wishes,<br>Nick   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T17:52:23+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nicholas Bowskill</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;80a04fd2.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;94f4be5f.1503">   <title>Re: [1] Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;94f4be5f.1503</link>   <description> I fear that I have not been clear in my message. Perhaps what is obvious to me doesn't enter the immediate perspective of others?<br>My point about VARK is that I link this strongly to the issue of diversity and disability - people who are partially sighted struggle with the visual (and read/write); people with auditory impairments struggle with aural delivery; those who are dyslexic struggle with reading and writing and those with motor impairment may struggle with the kinaesthetic. If we build our lessons to incorporate all modes of information transfer (not that I think that information transfer is [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T17:42:25+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>BLAND TOMKINSON</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;94f4be5f.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8bb719c4.1503">   <title>Re: [1] Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8bb719c4.1503</link>   <description> Yes, there is, which suggests that the mind/matter dualism prevents us from<br>fully understanding just how complex the relationship is between ourselves,<br>the environment and others. However, our sensory functions are shaped by<br>our experiences so when using them in any social situation, we may tend to<br>draw upon or become reliant upon any one of them in ways that prevent us<br>from engaging with phenomena differently. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T16:35:58+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Emma Davenport</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8bb719c4.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e638801b.1503">   <title>Re: [1] Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e638801b.1503</link>   <description> There is a branch of anthropology which deals with this, in relation to the cultural context.<br><br>From: Online forum for SEDA, the Staff &amp; Educational Development Association [mailto:SEDA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] On Behalf Of Nicholas Bowskill<br>Sent: 06 March 2015 16:18<br>To: SEDA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles?<br><br>Our senses function as interactive mediators between the mind and the social environment, don't they? Therefore it is surely only the social situation, or being mindful of particular social identities etc., that determines whether any one or more of our senses has *saliency* in a given moment (I think saliency may [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T16:24:00+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>David Andrew</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e638801b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ceedf45b.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ceedf45b.1503</link>   <description> Our senses function as interactive mediators between the mind and the<br>social environment, don't they? Therefore it is surely only the social<br>situation, or being mindful of particular social identities<br>etc., that determines whether any one or more of our<br>senses has *saliency* in a given moment (I think saliency may be more<br>accurate than 'preferences' because it is not always a conscious selection). [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T16:17:46+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nicholas Bowskill</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ceedf45b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5f05b9aa.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5f05b9aa.1503</link>   <description> Hello,<br>This is a fascinating debate, given that I have just delivered a lecture on<br>phenomenology to second year design students where I argued that if<br>perception is embodied, it must draw upon all sensory facilities. I agree<br>that learning styles are problematic but appreciate that they attempt to<br>describe what are no doubt complex processes of social cognition. However,<br>I will strongly suggest that everyone draws upon all their sensory<br>facilities when learning - it is impossible not to do so from a<br>phenomenological perspective. We are all multi-sensory learners, all the<br>time. The issue is in the detail [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T15:22:45+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Emma Davenport</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5f05b9aa.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e852bc9d.1503">   <title>Re: [1] Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e852bc9d.1503</link>   <description> Hello Bland<br>Alternatively that element of the learning process is unconscious for that person \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds the most efficient way!<br><br>The problem with \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlearning styles\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is that the way the concept is used closes down curiosity rather than enabling it.<br><br>David<br><br>From: Online forum for SEDA, the Staff &amp; Educational Development Association [mailto:SEDA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] On Behalf Of BLAND TOMKINSON<br>Sent: 06 March 2015 15:02<br>To: SEDA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T15:15:41+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>David Andrew</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e852bc9d.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;2e475fef.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;2e475fef.1503</link>   <description> Whilst I am happy to concede that the concept of &quot;learning styles&quot; is anathema to many, I cannot accept that we are all visual and auditory and read/write and kinaesthetic learners. One of my main reasons for introducing the concept of VARK is that some individuals are unable to access these modes of learning or can do so only with considerable difficulty.<br>C Bland Tomkinson BSc BA MEd PFHEA FAUA<br>Visiting Lecturer, University of Manchester<br>Special Consultant, South East University, Nanjing<br>Associate Editor, HERD<br>----Original message----<br>From : K.Hellman@exeter.ac.uk<br>Date : 06/03/2015 - 14:30 (GMTST)<br>To : bland.tomkinson@BTINTERNET.COM, SEDA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T15:02:13+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>BLAND TOMKINSON</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;2e475fef.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;bb73530d.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;bb73530d.1503</link>   <description> Dear all<br><br>Maybe it has already been mentioned that the debate has moved on from Learning Styles as an effective diagnostic tool and many have criticised Honey and Mumford\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Leaning Styles.<br><br>John Hattie and Gregory Yates in \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdVisible Learning and the Science of How We Learn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (2014), debunk the learning styles myth: [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T14:30:17+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Hellman, Kate</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;bb73530d.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e78d3714.1503">   <title>Higher Education Academy Professional Recognition writing retreats - Senior and Principal Fellowship </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e78d3714.1503</link>   <description> Are you interested in achieving Senior or Principal Fellowship of the Higher Education Academy? If so our writing retreats may be of interest to you.<br><br>We have two dates available depending on which category of Fellowship you are aiming for.<br><br>* Senior Fellow writing retreat, 27 May 2015, The University of Edinburgh - https://www.heacademy.ac.uk/events-conferences/event10198 [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T13:22:31+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Rajesh Dhimar</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e78d3714.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;131cb3ef.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;131cb3ef.1503</link>   <description> Hi, Mike<br>Whilst it is not indicative that different styles are appropriate for different disciplines, a study we did a little while ago (Hill, F., Tomkinson, B.,<br>Hiley, A., &amp; Dobson, H. (2014). Learning style preferences: an<br>examination of differences amongst students with different disciplinary<br>backgrounds. Innovations in Education and Teaching International.) suggested that there were differences in approach by students of different disciplinary backgrounds. I know that some work had been done eons ago using the MBTI both to look at learning preferences and also disciplinary differences, but I don't seem to have kept any references to the work. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T09:11:48+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>BLAND TOMKINSON</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;131cb3ef.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;d8ea4ee2.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;d8ea4ee2.1503</link>   <description> Can I just add two good books reviewing much of the research on intellectual styles:<br><br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Malleability of Intellectual Styles\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (Zhang, 2013; Cambridge University Press).<br>Forthcoming: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Value of Intellectual Styles\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (Cambridge University Press).<br><br>I guess the title of the first book raises the issue of malleability, depending on context etc.<br><br>My own, and others, research into student approaches to learning and teachers approaches to teaching is consistent with the idea of malleability. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T15:02:38+08:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>mprosser</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;d8ea4ee2.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;53b68983.1503">   <title>NUS Benchmarking Tools </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;53b68983.1503</link>   <description> Dear colleagues,<br><br>Some of you may be aware of the benchmarking tools NUS has produced in the last two years, on assessment and feedback&lt;http://www.nusconnect.org.uk/resources/open/highereducation/Feedback-and-Assessment-Benchmarking-Tool/&gt;, organisation and management&lt;http://www.nusconnect.org.uk/resources/open/highereducation/Organisation-and-management-benchmarking-tool/&gt;, and learning resources&lt;http://beta.nusconnect.org.uk/resources/learning-resources-benchmarking-tool&gt;, linked to the broad headings of the National Student Survey. We are currently evaluating the project that created these resources and would be very interested to talk to any university or college staff who have used the tools to aid enhancement. If you have used the tools within your institution and would be willing to talk to our evaluator for a brief interview, please drop me a message off-list. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T16:21:51+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Kate Little</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;53b68983.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ca80bbf.1503">   <title>Call for international case studies: Interventions supporting student progression </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ca80bbf.1503</link>   <description> The Higher Education Funding Council for England (<br>http://www.hefce.ac.uk/about/ ) has commissioned us to investigate<br>differences in students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd outcomes. By outcomes, we mean *differences in<br>progression within higher education, differences in degree attainment, and<br>differences in transitioning into postgraduate study or graduate-level<br>employment. *We are not requesting case studies concerning undergraduate<br>admissions or outreach. A full project description is available here:<br>http://www.hefce.ac.uk/whatwedo/wp/current/differential/ [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T18:10:10+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Anna Mountford-Zimdars</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ca80bbf.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7166131b.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7166131b.1503</link>   <description> Just wanted to chip in at the end of a most fascinating exchange of ideas and expertise. This is what SEDA is all about. I have definitely been a lurker but I think when this is pulled together we will have a very useful reference list and list of links. Perfect.<br>Thank you so much for sharing your expertise - so sorry I have not contributed...<br>Ruth [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T17:28:39+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ruth Pilkington</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7166131b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5b7181ae.1503">   <title>Re: Key Issues in Setting up an Interdisciplinary Module </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5b7181ae.1503</link>   <description> Dear Paul<br><br>I have been involved with interdisciplinary units for some time and I can concur with the view that money is ften the reason why such units do not continue. Prior to becoming involved in my own interdiscilianry units, I was certainly aware of issues of transfer values between departments (worse between faculties where different rules apply!) and in many cases otherwise successful units foundered because one department or another didn't like paying up. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T11:49:12+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>BLAND TOMKINSON</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5b7181ae.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;221044ec.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;221044ec.1503</link>   <description> Dear All,<br><br>Somewhat late in the day, but here are links to two further (and shorter) articles that I have found useful in stimulating debate about learning styles:<br><br>Timothy J. Landrum &amp; Kimberly A. McDuffie (2010): Learning Styles in the Age of Differentiated Instruction, Exceptionality, 18:1, 6-17<br>To link to this article: http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09362830903462441 [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T11:47:11+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Edwards, Corony</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;221044ec.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;79c4fc14.1503">   <title>Re: Key Issues in Setting up an Interdisciplinary Module </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;79c4fc14.1503</link>   <description> Hello Paul,<br><br>When you say 'key issues to be addressed' are you referring to course<br>content and which subjects should be included, or to logistic and pedagogic<br>issues of designing the module?<br><br>Some general thoughts on costing a new interdisciplinary module might be:<br><br>- Substantial extra time is often needed for initial preparation for<br>teaching staff to coordinate on content and how to present it, particularly<br>for designing assessments that will effectively assess interdisciplinary<br>learning and be fair to students from various subjects.<br>- Time costed for tutoring/helping students in how to translate ideas<br>across academic languages and expertise (since [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T11:27:48+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>David Morrison</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;79c4fc14.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5bf0b0b2.1503">   <title>Key Issues in Setting up an Interdisciplinary Module </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5bf0b0b2.1503</link>   <description> Dear All,<br>I've been asked to contribute to a budgetary costing proposal for a planned Faculty interdisciplinary module. The module is around the theme of Global Challenges, and it feeds into the strategy of producing graduates who are global citizens. The module will be at level 4 or level 5. Class size will be large &gt;150<br>The deadline is very tight. I'm writing to ask if anyone has advice about key issues to be addressed and key costs to be identified.<br>Many thanks,<br>Paul   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T10:36:38+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Paul Dearey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;5bf0b0b2.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;64076ade.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;64076ade.1503</link>   <description> Dear all, I've been following this debate and am really looking forward to reading the summary. Thanks to everyone who has contributed. It's really enabled me to think though some of the issues.<br><br>I have a supplemental question. In my organisation some parts use Learning Styles extensively. I've been aware of the debates for some some time and have been attempting to feed them some of the info so that they can think through the implications of using such a model. However I've now found out that 'using learning styles and evidencing how we do so' is part of an [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T10:13:23+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Hanna, Bridget</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;64076ade.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8228a6b2.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8228a6b2.1503</link>   <description> A very interesting discussion. I'm actually quite sceptical about learning<br>styles too, but had a dabble alongside this way back in 2005 in the first<br>edition of 'Making Learning Happen'. I deleted this chapter from the 2nd<br>edition in 2010, and likewise 2014. However, you might find it adds a<br>little to the discussion, so I've attached it here. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T10:10:34+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Phil Race</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8228a6b2.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ffab2e35.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ffab2e35.1503</link>   <description> Dear colleagues,<br><br>Thank you very much for your responses. I will shortly draw out some conclusions from your replies and distribute a summary of the key issues. If anyone else has anything to add on the subject of activities that help learners discover their learning style please let me know.<br><br>Thanks<br><br>Chris<br><br>Chris Martindale<br>Learning Enhancement<br>University of Derby<br>Tel. 01332-591212<br>c.martindale@derby.ac.uk&lt;mailto:c.martindale@derby.ac.uk&gt; [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T10:03:29+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Chris Martindale</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ffab2e35.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f45c4a5.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f45c4a5.1503</link>   <description> I think that you need the Hogwarts Sorting Hat... (though that has been mapped onto MBTI rather than learning styles).<br>This thread reminds me of a similar one on the US POD list a month ago and I apend my penn'orth to that debate, below.<br>However, I think that the concept of 'learning styles' causes an awful lot of pepople to get their underwear contorted - personally I can see some utility in the idea but I treat it with a bit of caution. Frank Coffield's work should have been the last word but, to my mind, the study was [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T19:22:09+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>BLAND TOMKINSON</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f45c4a5.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;d17840a5.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;d17840a5.1503</link>   <description> Pollyanna's account of her learning styles bib experience suggests a commitment from the school that I know I would be straight in to challenge if it involved my children.<br><br>I believe, however, those involved in The Education, Learning, Styles, Individual differences Network, ELSIN, http://elsinnetwork.com/index.php, would cite evidence to show things have moved on since Coffield et al's critique but I am not up to date with the latest developments. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T11:53:27+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Chris.Edwards</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;d17840a5.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b9a74cb1.1503">   <title>Two External Examining/Expert Roles Available </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b9a74cb1.1503</link>   <description> Dear SEDA colleagues,<br><br>we have two vacancies for external roles relating to our accredited taught provision here at the University of Bradford. Both are available immediately upon appointment and are for three years.<br><br>1) External Examiner for PGC in Higher Education Practice (accredited at D2) and two associated modules (accredited at D1). [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T11:39:45+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Peter Hughes</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b9a74cb1.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;746b48cd.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;746b48cd.1503</link>   <description> Chris,<br>I use a VARK questionnaire at the start of term and encourage the students to post the numbers of the VLE. I can then create a graph of the class learning styles.<br><br>[cid:image001.jpg@01D05596.33E93040]<br><br>It serves as a reminder to me of the individual needs of students. It helps the students understand that their style is likely to be different to the people sitting on either side and certainly very different to mine (high kinaesthetic). I don't spend long on it in class but encourage the students to understand their own mental models, those of others and to be able [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:41:20+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Robertson, Stephen</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;746b48cd.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f82999af.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f82999af.1503</link>   <description> the latest of Graham Gibbs's 53 - blogs looks at this issue and is a good<br>read.<br><br>Regards<br><br>Ian<br><br>On 3 March 2015 at 09:13, Boyd, Pete &lt;pete.boyd@cumbria.ac.uk&gt; wrote:<br><br>&gt; Chris<br>&gt;<br>&gt; I am with John on this\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdbelow is a note we provide to support two key<br>&gt; readings for student teachers\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Because Coffield is in post 16 I have added Pashler et al as it really<br>&gt; gets stuck into the critique\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Pete<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Learning Styles: Concepts and Evidence<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Sometimes a well written research paper seems worth sharing, especially<br> [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:48:43+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ian Scott</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;f82999af.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8c0206b8.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8c0206b8.1503</link>   <description> Bridget<br><br>I think you provide some really helpful nuances here of what we conceive of as learning style - although I like others would rather call them preferences. Even better I think Guy Claxton's work around, and use of the term, learning dispositions is also useful here - Chris, you can find a Launchpad to his stuff at www.guyclaxton.com, with apologies if you have already found it. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:55:53+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Alison James</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;8c0206b8.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b61a15e8.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b61a15e8.1503</link>   <description> Hi,<br>I often think of learning styles in a similar way to ideas about group<br>roles. Its a bit like reading tea leaves or using horoscopes as the basis<br>for learning. More seriously, its an idea that seems to locate<br>responsibility for learning at the individual level whilst ignoring social,<br>cultural and situational factors which may enable/constrain development. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:47:19+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Nicholas Bowskill</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b61a15e8.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;51d7fc68.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;51d7fc68.1503</link>   <description> Dear Chris &amp; SEDA colleagues<br><br>this is certainly an interesting discussion, thanks to Chris for his query.<br><br>I would just like to add some comments around the very different ways of learning in different disciplines and in different areas of work. We learn things differently in different settings, depending on the tasks involved. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:45:26+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Bridget Middlemas</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;51d7fc68.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7a9c5f75.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7a9c5f75.1503</link>   <description> Hallo Chris, here's my twopennyworth :)<br><br>I think focussing on 'learning styles' does a disservice to the complexity<br>of learning and avoids consideration of its essentially social nature. In<br>other sectors (and in HE) there is an appreciation, and a lot of research,<br>on the significance of mediating factors including mindset. I don't think<br>we do enough with students on understanding the process of learning, and<br>believe that this should be made more explicit in all of our teaching [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:31:55+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Hazel Messenger</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7a9c5f75.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b48b5547.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b48b5547.1503</link>   <description> hello All<br><br>learning styles is popular with some colleagues here but I make a point of<br>talking about why i don't/won't talk about learning styles in our CPD<br>scheme.....Cordeila thank you for the TPI link - very interesting.<br><br>Kind regards<br>Jane<br><br>Dr Jane Pritchard, SFHEA<br>Staff Development Manager (Academic)<br>Academic Staff Development<br>Human Resources Division<br>University of Bristol<br>Senate House<br>Tyndall Avenue<br>Clifton<br>Bristol<br>BS8 1TH<br>0117 928 7776 [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:32:18+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>J Pritchard</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;b48b5547.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e46a7ba3.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e46a7ba3.1503</link>   <description> This one by Fielder-Silverman is quick and provides the results immediately: http://www.engr.ncsu.edu/learningstyles/ilsweb.html<br><br>This may also be of interest, a critical review of all the learning styles by Coffield et al (2004):<br>http://www.downes.ca/files/docs/learning-styles.pdf<br><br>Kind regards, Laurie.<br>From: Online forum for SEDA, the Staff &amp; Educational Development Association [mailto:SEDA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] On Behalf Of Chris Martindale<br>Sent: 02 March 2015 21:16<br>To: SEDA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:10:29+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Blair, Laurie</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;e46a7ba3.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a1d3a5bf.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a1d3a5bf.1503</link>   <description> John<br>I would like to support you, as this can be a surprising response for people who have not yet engaged with Coffield. It surprises me that the idea of learning styles is still raised to the extent it is. Your response is fairly close to my own in these situations.<br>Note, however, the use of the idea of 'learning preference' in Chris' message. This is, I think, more useful because students often arrive at university with a particular idea about what works for them. I think one of the things we can do in higher education, indeed must do, [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:21:34+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Middleton, Andrew</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a1d3a5bf.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ede0c48f.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ede0c48f.1503</link>   <description> Dear Chris<br>I second John's comments!<br>On a visit to one of our teacher training schools one of my colleagues observed a lesson with children wearing a bib identifying their preferred learning style. The horror of this is that the children are tagged forever as one type of learner, and worse, the kids start to believe this is the only way they can learn. In addition to Coffield's findings that the vast majority of the learning styles inventories had no scientific basis what-so-ever, we also have to be mindful of the fact that learning in HE will demand a whole [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:20:32+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Pollyanna Magne</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;ede0c48f.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7b0ec697.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7b0ec697.1503</link>   <description> Whilst agreeing completely with John Cannning's points, here's a link to a quiz I use at the beginning of a PG Cert. just to get participants thinking about what they do and how they do it. As you'll see, it doesn't actually call any of the traits 'learning styles' which is all to the good! [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T04:19:57-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Cordelia Bryan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;7b0ec697.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;1067fe1b.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;1067fe1b.1503</link>   <description> Chris<br>I am with John on this...below is a note we provide to support two key readings for student teachers...<br>Because Coffield is in post 16 I have added Pashler et al as it really gets stuck into the critique...<br>Pete<br><br>Learning Styles: Concepts and Evidence<br>Sometimes a well written research paper seems worth sharing, especially when it tackles a contested area of knowledge. The paper entitled 'Learning Styles: Concepts and Evidence' (Pashler et al. 2008) is interesting because it is well-argued and tackles an area of education where unsubstantiated myths have gained considerable traction on the practice of teachers [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:13:22+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Boyd, Pete</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;1067fe1b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a6f02267.1503">   <title>Re: Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a6f02267.1503</link>   <description> Chris,<br>I'll bite, thought its not my area of expertise.<br>I think you've stepped into a minefield here.<br>Not only is the idea of learning styles itself contested e.g. Coffield http://sxills.nl/lerenlerennu/bronnen/Learning%20styles%20by%20Coffield%20e.a..pdf but we are probably doing a disservice to our students by promoting the belief that everyone has a 'learning style'. I accept people learn in different ways and prefer to learn in different ways, but if students believe they have a particular learning style they either neglect to develop skills in other areas or become convinced they can't undertake certain tasks because they conflict with their learning style- a [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:07:54+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>John Canning</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;a6f02267.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;35a16811.1503">   <title>Diagnostic tests to assess individual learning styles? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;35a16811.1503</link>   <description> Dear colleagues,<br><br>Can I draw upon the resources of your knowledge and experience? I am looking for a workshop activity that will help learners to discover their individual learning preference or style. I am aware of at least some of the models in the literature produced by Kolb, Gregoric, Fielder-Silverman or Fleming's VARK questionnaire. Ideally the test does not have to be too complicated and it has to include a visual outcome of some kind. Your suggestions would very welcome and save me having to 're-invent the wheel'. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T21:15:52+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Chris Martindale</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=seda;35a16811.1503</dc:identifier> </item>   </rdf:RDF>
